ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Through a survey of classics in non-fiction, philosophy, literature, art, music, and film, among other mediums, you can expect to gain a greater understanding of the way in which uncertainty affects the modern practice of medicine. However, this course goes so much further than that. You can expect to reflect and meditate on how one can be a better physician, but also how one can lead a more meaningful, satisfying, and generous life. In short, you will come away from the course with a greater understanding of yourself.

So much depth of insight on a variety of topics surrounding life, medicine, human fallibility, uncertainty, and so much more. A plethora of class trips to the YUAG, Beinecke, British Art Museum, Marsh Botanical Gardens, etc.

Developed a much deeper appreciation for the role of importance of the humanities to help us serve as effective doctors; a much clearer understanding of how intuition and reckoning with uncertainty can play an instrumental role (alongside traditional science) in diagnosis and treatment.

This is a class that does not just teach you the necessity of the humanities in the practice of medicine or the philosophies that dictate the balance between intuition and reasoning but the value of a life well lived.
I read a lot of authors, including actual doctors, and better understood the psyche of being a doctor as well as considered human fallibility and uncertainty more deeply.
backgrounds on classical and modern writers in medicine & humanities, overview of cognitive biases, & how to approach patients as people through their stories and your senses

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Dr. Morrison set this course up with a focus on his students. He arranged numerous field trips, guest speakers, and other experiences that highly enriched the content of the class. His lectures were fascinating.

If I were to make recommendations on how the course could be further improved, I would say that a slight tweaking of the syllabus might be necessary. I think instead of a collection of short passages from the authors some weeks, we would have benefited in just reading the works in their entirety. I think much of the secondary source material could also have been cut.

Otherwise, no major weaknesses to note.

There are so many strengths that cannot all be enumeratedthe quality of the lectures, the enthusiasm of Professor Morrison, all of the captivating class trips, the deep insights that we explore, the readings. This has literally been my favorite class at Yale so far.

Dr. Morrison is stellar.  He is invested deeply in his students' growth, and getting to learn from his reflections on the writers we read as well as on his own experiences in medicine was the absolute highlight of the course.

There are so many strengths to this course (starting with Dr. Morrison first and foremost). The lecture topics, nature of the assignments, field trips, guest speakers, and readings are so well curated and thought out. If I had to give a little bit of criticism it would just be that there was not as much time for class discussion regarding the readings; however, Dr. Morrison gives such amazing insight in his lectures that it would also be remiss to say that I would want them shortened.

I loved all of the readings, lectures, guest lecturers, and field trips, as well as the general course workload. I do kind of wish there was a better way of getting to know the other students and engaging with the reading, so maybe having a discussion forum that we'd have to post on a few times?
super engaging material! could be enriched by more time allotted for seminar-style discussion with students perspectives beyond lecture-style review of writers and their backgrounds

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course, if it is taught again. As a senior, I can safely say it was one of the greatest courses I took at Yale.
Yes, yes, 100 times yes. The most fascinating, deep, and insightful class!!!

Dr. Morrison is stellar.  He is invested deeply in his students' growth, and getting to learn from his reflections on the writers we read as well as on his own experiences in medicine was the absolute highlight of the course.
I would absolutely recommend this course. Truly a path of self-discovery.
Absolutely. This is probably my favorite class I've ever taken at Yale.

Yes! If you have the opportunity to take this course definitely take it. While it may seem like a pre-med course, anyone can benefit from the lessons in the class. The course does focus heavily in philosophy, which can be challenging at times, but the life lessons gained from the readings are profoundly enlightening. Dr. Morrison is also a delight to have as a professor. He is so incredibly passionate about teaching and compassionate to his students. He also continuously finds ways to make the course interesting with amazing guest speakers and field trips.
Yes, absolutely

Yes, I loved this class a lot. Never have I been able to find such a balance of my interests in literature, care, and biology. All the lectures and field trips were so fun and really helped me think about practicing medicine in new light.

Yes!!! If you can get in, do take it, its one of the few classes at Yale that intersects these important fields, and any aspiring physician would do well to learn more about the art of medicine beyond just the science
